fr.sii.ogham.sms.builder

Class SmsBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.core.fluent.AbstractParent<MessagingBuilder>
      • fr.sii.ogham.sms.builder.SmsBuilder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Builder<ConditionalSender>, Parent<MessagingBuilder>

    public class SmsBuilder
extends AbstractParent<MessagingBuilder>
implements Builder<ConditionalSender>
    Configures how to send Sms messages. It allows to:
    • register and configure several sender implementations
    • register and configure several template engines for parsing templates as message content
    • configure handling of missing Sms information
    • configure number format handling
    You can send a Sms using the minimal behavior and using Cloudhopper implementation: 
     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .sms()
     .sender(CloudhopperBuilder.class)   // enable SMS sending using Cloudhopper
       .host("your SMPP server host")
       .port("your SMPP server port")
       .systemId("your SMPP system_id")
       .password("an optional password")
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the sms
 service.send(new Sms()
   .from("sender phone number")
   .content("sms content")
   .to("recipient phone number"));
    You can also send a Sms using a template (using Freemarker for example): The Freemarker template ("sms/sample.txt.ftl"): 
     Sms content with variables: ${name} ${value}
    Then you can send the Sms like this: 
     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .sms()
     .sender(CloudhopperBuilder.class)   // enable SMS sending using Cloudhopper
       .host("your SMPP server host")
       .port("your SMPP server port")
       .systemId("your SMPP system_id")
       .password("an optional password")
       .and()
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerSmsBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the sms
 service.send(new Sms()
   .from("sender phone number")
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:sms/sample.txt.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient phone number"));

    Instead of explicitly configures SMPP host/port/system_id/password in your code, it could be better to externalize the configuration in a properties file for example (for example a file named "sms.properties" in the classpath). The previous example becomes: 

     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .environment()
     .properties("sms.properties")
     .and()
   .sms()
     .sender(CloudhopperBuilder.class)   // enable SMS sending using Cloudhopper
       .host("${smpp.host}")
       .port("${smpp.port}")
       .systemId("${smpp.system-id}")
       .password("${smpp.password}")
       .and()
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerSmsBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the sms
 service.send(new Sms()
   .from("sender phone number")
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:sms/sample.txt.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient phone number"));
    The content of the file "sms.properties": 
     smpp.host=your SMPP server host
 smpp.port=your SMPP server port
 smpp.system-id=your SMPP system_id
 smpp.password=an optional password
    Some fields of the SMS may be automatically filled by a default value if they are not defined. For example, the sender phone number could be configured only once for your application: 
     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .environment()
     .properties("sms.properties")
     .and()
   .sms()
     .sender(CloudhopperBuilder.class)   // enable SMS sending using Cloudhopper
       .host().properties("${smpp.host}").and()
       .port().properties("${smpp.port}").and()
       .systemId().properties("${smpp.system-id}").and()
       .password().properties("${smpp.password}").and()
       .and()
     .autofill()    // enables and configures autofilling
       .from()
         .defaultValue().properties("${sms.sender.number}").and()
         .and()
       .and()
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerSmsBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the sms (now the sender phone number can be omitted)
 service.send(new Sms()
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:sms/sample.txt.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient phone number"));
    The new content of the file "sms.properties": 
     smpp.host=your SMPP server host
 smpp.port=your SMPP server port
 smpp.system-id=your SMPP system_id
 smpp.password=an optional password
 sms.sender.number=the sender phone number

    All the previous examples are provided to understand what can be configured. Hopefully, Ogham provides auto-configuration with a default behavior that fits 95% of usages. This auto-configuration is provided by MessagingConfigurers. Those configurers are automatically applied when using predefined MessagingBuilders like MessagingBuilder.minimal() and MessagingBuilder.standard(). The previous sample using standard configuration becomes: 

     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties("sms.properties")
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the sms
 service.send(new Sms()
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:sms/sample.txt.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient phone number"));
    The new content of the file "sms.properties": 
     ogham.sms.smpp.host=your SMPP server host
 ogham.sms.smpp.port=your SMPP server port
 ogham.sms.smpp.system-id=your SMPP system_id
 ogham.sms.smpp.password=an optional password
 ogham.sms.from.default-value=the sender phone number

    You can also use the auto-configuration for benefit from default behaviors and override some behaviors for your needs: 

     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties("sms.properties")
     .and()
   .sms()
     .autofill()
       .from()
         .defaultValue().properties("${sms.sender.number}").and()   // overrides default sender phone number property
         .and()
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the sms
 service.send(new Sms()
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:sms/sample.txt.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient phone number"));
    The new content of the file "sms.properties": 
     ogham.sms.smpp.host=your SMPP server host
 ogham.sms.smpp.port=your SMPP server port
 ogham.sms.smpp.system-id=your SMPP system_id
 ogham.sms.smpp.password=an optional password
 sms.sender.number=the sender phone number
    Author:
    Aurélien Baudet

    • Constructor Detail

      • SmsBuilder

        public SmsBuilder(MessagingBuilder parent,
                  BuildContext buildContext)
        Initializes the builder with a parent builder. The parent builder is used when calling AbstractParent.and() method. The BuildContext is used to evaluate properties when build() method is called.
        Parameters:
        parent - the parent builder
        buildContext - for registering instances and property evaluation

    • Method Detail

      • autofill

        public AutofillSmsBuilder autofill()
        Configures how Ogham will add default values to the Sms if some information is missing. If sender phone number is missing, a default one can be defined in configuration properties. If recipient phone number is missing, a default one can be defined in configuration properties. 
         
        builder
          .autofill()
            .from()
              .defaultValue().properties("${ogham.sms.from.default-value}").and()
                .and()
            .to()
              .defaultValue().properties("${ogham.sms.to.default-value}").and()
                .and()
            .and()
        Returns:
        the builder to configure autofilling of SMS

      • numbers

        public PhoneNumbersBuilder numbers()
        Configures the phone number conversions (from a PhoneNumber to an AddressedPhoneNumber). The PhoneNumber is used by the developer to provide a simple phone number without knowing how phone number works (no need to handle formats, addressing, countries...). The AddressedPhoneNumber is used by Ogham implementations to have a phone number that is usable by a technical system. For example: 
         
        builder
          .numbers()
            .from()
              .format()
                .alphanumericCode().properties("${ogham.sms.from.alphanumeric-code-format.enable}").defaultValue(true).and()
                .shortCode().properties("${ogham.sms.from.short-code-format.enable}").defaultValue(true).and()
                .internationalNumber().properties("${ogham.sms.from.international-format.enable}").defaultValue(true).and()
                .and()
              .and()
            .to()
              .format()
                .internationalNumber().properties("${ogham.sms.to.international-format.enable}").defaultValue(true);
        Returns:
        the builder to configure phone number formats

      • template

        public <T extends Builder<? extends TemplateParser>> T template(Class<T> builderClass)
        Registers and configures a TemplateParser through a dedicated builder. For example: 
         .register(ThymeleafSmsBuilder.class)
     .detector(new ThymeleafEngineDetector());

        Your Builder may implement VariantBuilder to handle template Variants (used for MultiTemplateContent that provide a single path to templates with different extensions for example).

        Your Builder may also implement DetectorBuilder in order to indicate which kind of templates your TemplateParser is able to parse. If your template parse is able to parse any template file you are using, you may not need to implement DetectorBuilder.

        In order to be able to keep chaining, you builder instance may provide a constructor with two arguments:

        • The type of the parent builder (&lt;P&gt;)
        • The BuildContext instance
        If you don't care about chaining, just provide a default constructor.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the builder
        Parameters:
        builderClass - the builder class to instantiate
        Returns:
        the builder to configure the implementation

      • customSender

        public SmsBuilder customSender(MessageSender sender)
        Registers a custom message sender implementation.

        If your custom implementation is annotated by one or several of:

        • RequiredClass
        • RequiredProperty
        • RequiredClasses
        • RequiredProperties
        Then if condition evaluation returns true, your implementation will be used. If you provide several annotations, your implementation will be used only if all conditions are met (and operator).

        If your custom implementation implements ActivableAtRuntime, and the provided condition evaluation returns true, then your implementation will be used. See MessageConditions to build your condition.

        If neither annotations nor implementation of ActivableAtRuntime is used, then your custom implementation will be always used. All other implementations (even standard ones) will never be used.

        Parameters:
        sender - the sender to register
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • sender

        public <T extends Builder<? extends MessageSender>> T sender(Class<T> builderClass)
        Registers and configures sender through a dedicated builder. For example: 
         .sender(CloudhopperBuilder.class)
     .host("localhost");

        If your custom builder is annotated by one or several of:

        • RequiredClass
        • RequiredProperty
        • RequiredClasses
        • RequiredProperties
        Then if condition evaluation returns true, your built implementation will be used. If you provide several annotations, your built implementation will be used only if all conditions are met (and operator).

        If your custom builder implements ActivableAtRuntime, and the provided condition evaluation returns true, then your built implementation will be used. See MessageConditions to build your condition.

        If neither annotations nor implementation of ActivableAtRuntime is used, then your built implementation will be always used. All other implementations (even standard ones) will never be used.

        In order to be able to keep chaining, you builder instance may provide a constructor with one argument with the type of the parent builder (SmsBuilder). If you don't care about chaining, just provide a default constructor.

        Your builder may return null when calling Builder.build(). In this case it means that your implementation can't be used due to current environment. Your implementation is then not registered.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the builder
        Parameters:
        builderClass - the builder class to instantiate
        Returns:
        the builder to configure the implementation

      • autoRetry

        public RetryBuilder<SmsBuilder> autoRetry()
        Configure automatic retry if message couldn't be sent. For example: 
         .autoRetry()
   .fixedDelay()
     .maxRetries().properties("${ogham.sms.send-retry.max-attempts}").and()
     .delay().properties("${ogham.sms.send-retry.delay-between-attempts}")

        This builder lets you configure:

        • The retry strategy:
          • FixedDelayRetry: wait for a fixed delay after the last failure
          • FixedIntervalRetry: wait for a fixed delay between executions (do not wait for the end of the action)
          • ExponentialDelayRetry: start with a delay, the next delay will be doubled on so on
          • PerExecutionDelayRetry: provide a custom delay for each execution
        • The RetryExecutor implementation
        • The Awaiter implementation
        • The Condition used to determine if the raised error should trigger a retry or not
        Returns:
        the builder to configure retry management

      • build

        public ConditionalSender build()
        Description copied from interface: Builder
        Instantiate and configures the instance.
        Specified by:
        build in interface Builder<ConditionalSender>
        Returns:
        The built instance
